goal.ch: ME3053 is an introductory modern physics course designed for mechanical engineering students in the junior/senior year. The so-called modern physics refers to the revolutionary concepts and theories developed in the early 20th century, including the theory of relativity and quantum mechanics. Applications of modern physics are broad, spanning nuclear science, materials science, electronics, and quantum science/technology, to name a few. The primary goal of ME3053 is to introduce the students to the fundamental principles of modern physics, preparing them for more advanced courses in materials, semiconductor, electronics, and quantum engineering.
goal.en: ME3053 is an introductory modern physics course designed for mechanical engineering students in the junior/senior year. The so-called modern physics refers to the revolutionary concepts and theories developed in the early 20th century, including the theory of relativity and quantum mechanics. Applications of modern physics are broad, spanning nuclear science, materials science, electronics, and quantum science/technology, to name a few. The primary goal of ME3053 is to introduce the students to the fundamental principles of modern physics, preparing them for more advanced courses in materials, semiconductor, electronics, and quantum engineering.

outline.ch: Key topics of ME3053 include the special theory of relativity, wave-particle duality, matter waves, the Schrödinger equation and its application to hydrogen atoms, and introductory atomic, molecular and solid-state physics. If time allows, statistical physics will be discussed.
outline.en: Key topics of ME3053 include the special theory of relativity, wave-particle duality, matter waves, the Schrödinger equation and its application to hydrogen atoms, and introductory atomic, molecular and solid-state physics. If time allows, statistical physics will be discussed.
